elements.content: Two new zinc compounds, [Zn2(mtz)­(nic)2(OH)] n ·0.5nH2O (1) and [Zn­(phtz)­(nic)]2n (2) (Hmtz = 5-methyltetrazole, Hphtz = 5-phenyltetrazole, Hnic = nicotinic acid), have been synthesized by a dual-ligand approach under solvothermal conditions. The compounds were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, elemental analysis, and infrared spectroscopy, respectively. The X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that both compounds exhibit a noncentrosymmetric polar packing arrangement. Compound 1 is a 3D framework constructed from the zigzag chain subunits of [Zn­(nic)]+ with a 4-connected “irl” topology. Compound 2 possesses a 2D 4-connected ‘“sql” topology constructed from the linear chain subunit of [Zn­(nic)]+, which are linked together with phtz– ligands. Impressively, both of the two compounds display second-harmonic generation response and ferroelectric behaviors. Furthermore, the photoluminescence of the compounds was also investigated.
elements.clean_text: Two new zinc compounds, [Zn2(mtz)(nic)2(OH)] n ⋅0.5nH2O (1) and [Zn(phtz)(nic)]2n  (2) (Hmtz = 5-methyltetrazole, Hphtz = 5-phenyltetrazole, Hnic = nicotinic acid), have been synthesized by a dual-ligand approach under solvothermal conditions. The compounds were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, elemental analysis, and infrared spectroscopy, respectively. The X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that both compounds exhibit a noncentrosymmetric polar packing arrangement. Compound 1 is a 3D framework constructed from the zigzag chain subunits of [Zn(nic)]+ with a 4-connected "irl" topology. Compound 2 possesses a 2D 4-connected ‘"sql" topology constructed from the linear chain subunit of [Zn(nic)]+, which are linked together with phtz- ligands. Impressively, both of the two compounds display second-harmonic generation response and ferroelectric behaviors. Furthermore, the photoluminescence of the compounds was also investigated.

elements.content: Two new noncentrosymmetric ZnII compounds have been prepared from mixing the asymmetric and symmetric bridging ligands. Both of them exhibit good NLO activities, ferroelectric behaviors, and fluorescent properties.
elements.clean_text: Two new noncentrosymmetric ZnII compounds have been prepared from mixing the asymmetric and symmetric bridging ligands. Both of them exhibit good NLO activities, ferroelectric behaviors, and fluorescent properties.

elements.content: Nonlinear optical (NLO), pyroelectric, piezoelectric, and ferroelectric materials are useful in various areas. Of particular importance are NLO second-harmonic generation (SHG) and ferroelectricity, which are the desired materials in switchable NLO devices, light modulators, information storage, and ferroelectric random access memories. The rational synthesis and design of noncentrosymmetric or polar compounds have attracted much attention in the multifunctional materials field. Traditionally, research of SHG-active and ferroelectricity is mainly focused on pure inorganic compounds such as KH2PO4 (KDP), BaTiO3, and LiNbO3. Investigation of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) possessing NLO response and ferroelectric behaviors, which combine the advantages of the inorganic metal ions and organic ligands, still remains in its infancy. It is a great challenge to synthesize MOFs with both ferroelectric and NLO properties because such compounds not only must crystallize in acentric space groups but also should belong to 1 of the 10 polar point groups. Generally, the most effective and straightforward strategy is to use a homochiral organic ligand as building block to assemble these multifunctional MOFs. The application of the homochiral organic ligand will greatly increase the possibility of constructing MOFs that would crystallize in 1 of the 10 polar point groups essential for NLO-active or ferroelectric behavior. However, the synthesis and separation of the homochiral organic ligand is always complex and costly. Moreover, the NLO-active or ferroelectric material may not always be obtained when the homochiral ligands are applied. Recently, some research groups have prepared a few MOFs with NLO-active or ferroelectric behaviors by using asymmetric bridging ligands replacing the homochiral ligands. It confirmed that NLO-active or ferroelectric MOFs can be efficiently generated by the introduction of an asymmetric bridging ligand under the solvothermal reaction conditions. The key factor is that the use of asymmetrical ligands will ensure the absence of inversion centers on the bridging ligands. When both the metal center and the bridging ligand lack a center of symmetry, it will greatly guarantee the acentricity of the network.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Nonlinear optical (NLO), pyroelectric, piezoelectric, and ferroelectric materials are useful in various areas. Of particular importance are NLO second-harmonic generation (SHG) and ferroelectricity, which are the desired materials in switchable NLO devices, light modulators, information storage, and ferroelectric random access memories. The rational synthesis and design of noncentrosymmetric or polar compounds have attracted much attention in the multifunctional materials field. Traditionally, research of SHG-active and ferroelectricity is mainly focused on pure inorganic compounds such as KH2PO4 (KDP), BaTiO3, and LiNbO3. Investigation of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) possessing NLO response and ferroelectric behaviors, which combine the advantages of the inorganic metal ions and organic ligands, still remains in its infancy. It is a great challenge to synthesize MOFs with both ferroelectric and NLO properties because such compounds not only must crystallize in acentric space groups but also should belong to 1 of the 10 polar point groups. Generally, the most effective and straightforward strategy is to use a homochiral organic ligand as building block to assemble these multifunctional MOFs. The application of the homochiral organic ligand will greatly increase the possibility of constructing MOFs that would crystallize in 1 of the 10 polar point groups essential for NLO-active or ferroelectric behavior. However, the synthesis and separation of the homochiral organic ligand is always complex and costly. Moreover, the NLO-active or ferroelectric material may not always be obtained when the homochiral ligands are applied. Recently, some research groups have prepared a few MOFs with NLO-active or ferroelectric behaviors by using asymmetric bridging ligands replacing the homochiral ligands. It confirmed that NLO-active or ferroelectric MOFs can be efficiently generated by the introduction of an asymmetric bridging ligand under the solvothermal reaction conditions. The key factor is that the use of asymmetrical ligands will ensure the absence of inversion centers on the bridging ligands. When both the metal center and the bridging ligand lack a center of symmetry, it will greatly guarantee the acentricity of the network.

elements.content: In the literature, it is a general strategy to assemble noncentric MOFs by using a single asymmetric bridging ligand and get some 2D coordination networks. However, mixing an asymmetric bridging ligand with a symmetric bridging ligand to assemble noncentric MOFs was rarely presented up to now. Encouraged by these works, we envisioned that an asymmetric bridging ligand could provide convenient access to MOF crystals with SHG response and ferroelectricity and also could lead to more diverse frameworks.
elements.clean_text: In the literature, it is a general strategy to assemble noncentric MOFs by using a single asymmetric bridging ligand and get some 2D coordination networks. However, mixing an asymmetric bridging ligand with a symmetric bridging ligand to assemble noncentric MOFs was rarely presented up to now. Encouraged by these works, we envisioned that an asymmetric bridging ligand could provide convenient access to MOF crystals with SHG response and ferroelectricity and also could lead to more diverse frameworks.

elements.content: Nicotinic acid, as a good asymmetric bridging ligand with pyridyl-nitrogen and carboxyl-oxygen donor atoms, has been widely used to construct MOFs. When the bent configuration of this ligand links tetrahedrally connected metal centers, the metal centers will have at most C 2v symmetry and thus will not possess a center of symmetry. This will be likely to create noncentric polymeric compounds. Moreover, the tetrazole-based ligand also has strong coordination ability with metal because of the aromaticity and multiple N-donor atoms and has been utilized as multifunctional organic linkers for the generating coordination polymers. With the presence of two different negatively charged ligands in the synthesis, materials with interesting structures and properties are expected. With this dual-ligand synthetic strategy and as a part of our ongoing research on the construction of ferroelectric complexes, two new noncentric MOFs, [Zn2(mtz)­(nic)2(OH)] n ·0.5nH2O (1) and [Zn­(phtz)­(nic)] n (2), have been successfully synthesized under solvothermal conditions. The materials are constructed by tetrahedrally connected Zn2+ centers, asymmetric bridging ligands, and tetrazole-based ligands. The ferroelectric behaviors, NLO-active, thermal stabilities, and photoluminescence properties of the two compounds have been investigated.
elements.clean_text: Nicotinic acid, as a good asymmetric bridging ligand with pyridyl-nitrogen and carboxyl-oxygen donor atoms, has been widely used to construct MOFs. When the bent configuration of this ligand links tetrahedrally connected metal centers, the metal centers will have at most C 2v  symmetry and thus will not possess a center of symmetry. This will be likely to create noncentric polymeric compounds. Moreover, the tetrazole-based ligand also has strong coordination ability with metal because of the aromaticity and multiple N-donor atoms and has been utilized as multifunctional organic linkers for the generating coordination polymers. With the presence of two different negatively charged ligands in the synthesis, materials with interesting structures and properties are expected. With this dual-ligand synthetic strategy and as a part of our ongoing research on the construction of ferroelectric complexes, two new noncentric MOFs, [Zn2(mtz)(nic)2(OH)] n ⋅0.5nH2O (1) and [Zn(phtz)(nic)] n  (2), have been successfully synthesized under solvothermal conditions. The materials are constructed by tetrahedrally connected Zn2+ centers, asymmetric bridging ligands, and tetrazole-based ligands. The ferroelectric behaviors, NLO-active, thermal stabilities, and photoluminescence properties of the two compounds have been investigated.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used without further purification. Infrared spectra were recorded in the range of 4000–400 cm–1 on a PerkinElmer FT-IR spectrum 2000 spectrometer by using KBr pellets for 1. Infrared spectra were recorded in the range of 4000–550 cm–1 on a Nicolet 6700 FT-IR spectrometer for 2. Elemental analysis was determined with a PerkinElmer model 240C instrument. Thermal analysis was performed on a Delta Series TGA7 instrument in a N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min from 30 to 700 °C. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were obtained by using a Rigaku D/MAX 2500 V/PC diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.54056 Å) radiation. A step size of 0.05° and a counting time of 1.2s/step were applied in a 2θ range of 5.0–60.0°. The electric hysteresis loops were recorded on a Ferroelectric Tester Multiferroic made by Radiant Technologies, Inc. Powder SHG measurements were carried out by the Kurtz–Perry method. The measurements were performed by using a Q-switched Nd:YAG laser at 1064 nm with an input pulse of 350 mV.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Reagents and Physical Measurements

All reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used without further purification. Infrared spectra were recorded in the range of 4000-400 cm-1 on a PerkinElmer FT-IR spectrum 2000 spectrometer by using KBr pellets for 1. Infrared spectra were recorded in the range of 4000-550 cm-1 on a Nicolet 6700 FT-IR spectrometer for 2. Elemental analysis was determined with a PerkinElmer model 240C instrument. Thermal analysis was performed on a Delta Series TGA7 instrument in a N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min from 30 to 700 °C. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were obtained by using a Rigaku D/MAX 2500 V/PC diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.54056 Å) radiation. A step size of 0.05° and a counting time of 1.2s/step were applied in a 2θ range of 5.0-60.0°. The electric hysteresis loops were recorded on a Ferroelectric Tester Multiferroic made by Radiant Technologies, Inc. Powder SHG measurements were carried out by the Kurtz-Perry method. The measurements were performed by using a Q-switched Nd:YAG laser at 1064 nm with an input pulse of 350 mV.

elements.content: A mixture of ZnSO4·7H2O (0.575 g, 2 mmol), Hmtz (0.168 g, 2 mmol), Hnic (0.122g, 1.0 mmol), NaOH (0.040g, 1.0 mmol), ethanol (2 mL), and water (8 mL) was stirred for 30 min in air, then sealed in a 23 mL Teflon autoclave, and heated at 130 °C for 3 days. After the sample was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C/h, colorless block crystals were obtained in ca. 38% yield based on Zn. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3450 (m), 2919 (w), 2850 (w), 2343 (w), 1599 (m), 1556 (m), 1488 (s), 1384 (vs), 1249 (m), 1182 (m), 1094 (m), 699 (s), 491 (m). () Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C28H26N12O11Zn4: (M r = 968.09) C, 34.93; H, 2.72; N, 17.47; found: C, 34.08; H, 2.48; N, 17.62.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

Synthesis of [Zn2(mtz)(nic)2(OH)] n ⋅0.5nH2O (1)

A mixture of ZnSO4⋅7H2O (0.575 g, 2 mmol), Hmtz (0.168 g, 2 mmol), Hnic (0.122g, 1.0 mmol), NaOH (0.040g, 1.0 mmol), ethanol (2 mL), and water (8 mL) was stirred for 30 min in air, then sealed in a 23 mL Teflon autoclave, and heated at 130 °C for 3 days. After the sample was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C/h, colorless block crystals were obtained in ca. 38% yield based on Zn. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3450 (m), 2919 (w), 2850 (w), 2343 (w), 1599 (m), 1556 (m), 1488 (s), 1384 (vs), 1249 (m), 1182 (m), 1094 (m), 699 (s), 491 (m). () Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C28H26N12O11Zn4: (M r = 968.09) C, 34.93; H, 2.72; N, 17.47; found: C, 34.08; H, 2.48; N, 17.62.

elements.content: Similarly, complex 2 was prepared in the same manner as that for 1 but with Hphtz (0.292 g, 2 mmol) to replace Hmtz. Colorless block crystals were obtained in ca. 32% yield based on Zn. IR (cm–1): 3060 (m), 1610 (m), 1530 (m), 1460 (s), 1390 (s), 1320 (m), 1290 (w), 1200 (w), 1200 (m), 1180 (s), 1020 (s), 931 (m), 854 (w), 783 (s), 731 (s), 687 (s), 600 (m). () Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C26H18N10O4Zn2: (M r = 665.24) C, 46.94; H, 2.73; N, 21.05; found: C, 46.73; H, 2.52; N, 21.32.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Zn(phtz)(nic)]2n  (2)

Similarly, complex 2 was prepared in the same manner as that for 1 but with Hphtz (0.292 g, 2 mmol) to replace Hmtz. Colorless block crystals were obtained in ca. 32% yield based on Zn. IR (cm-1): 3060 (m), 1610 (m), 1530 (m), 1460 (s), 1390 (s), 1320 (m), 1290 (w), 1200 (w), 1200 (m), 1180 (s), 1020 (s), 931 (m), 854 (w), 783 (s), 731 (s), 687 (s), 600 (m). () Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C26H18N10O4Zn2: (M r = 665.24) C, 46.94; H, 2.73; N, 21.05; found: C, 46.73; H, 2.52; N, 21.32.

elements.content: Suitable single crystals of two complexes were mounted on glass fibers for X-ray measurement. Reflection data were collected at room temperature on a Rigaku Saturn 724 CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Crystal structures were solved by the direct method. All calculations were performed using the SHELX-97 program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2 with anisotropic thermal parameters. Hydrogen atoms associated with C atoms in compounds 1 and 2 were fixed at calculated positions and refined by using a riding mode. The hydroxyl hydrogen atoms and H atoms of water molecules for 1 were found from difference maps and refined with an O–H distance restraint of 0.82(1) Å. Crystal data and details of the data collection and the structure refinements are given in . Selected bond lengths and bond angles of the compounds are listed in .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Suitable single crystals of two complexes were mounted on glass fibers for X-ray measurement. Reflection data were collected at room temperature on a Rigaku Saturn 724 CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Crystal structures were solved by the direct method. All calculations were performed using the SHELX-97 program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2 with anisotropic thermal parameters. Hydrogen atoms associated with C atoms in compounds 1 and 2 were fixed at calculated positions and refined by using a riding mode. The hydroxyl hydrogen atoms and H atoms of water molecules for 1 were found from difference maps and refined with an O-H distance restraint of 0.82(1) Å. Crystal data and details of the data collection and the structure refinements are given in . Selected bond lengths and bond angles of the compounds are listed in .

Compound 1 crystallizes in the noncentrosymmetric space group Ccc2, which belongs to the polar point group C 2v . The asymmetrical unit of 1 contains one Zn atom, one nicotinic ligand, half a mtz– ligand, half a hydroxide group, and half a free water molecule. As shown in a, the Zn­(II) ion is coordinated with two nitrogen atoms from a nic– ligand (N1) and mtz– ligand (N2), two oxygen atoms from the hydroxide group (O3) and the other nic ligand (O1ii), respectively, to form a slightly distorted ZnN2O2 tetrahedron with the cis-bond angles ranging from 103.3(1) to 106.5(1)°. All the Zn–N and Zn–O bond lengths are in the normal range and comparable to those of the Zn­(II)-tetrazole and the Zn­(II)-nicotinate compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of [Zn2(mtz)(nic)2(OH)] n ⋅0.5nH2O (1)

Compound 1 crystallizes in the noncentrosymmetric space group Ccc2, which belongs to the polar point group C 2v . The asymmetrical unit of 1 contains one Zn atom, one nicotinic ligand, half a mtz- ligand, half a hydroxide group, and half a free water molecule. As shown in a, the Zn(II) ion is coordinated with two nitrogen atoms from a nic- ligand (N1) and mtz- ligand (N2), two oxygen atoms from the hydroxide group (O3) and the other nic ligand (O1ii), respectively, to form a slightly distorted ZnN2O2 tetrahedron with the cis-bond angles ranging from 103.3(1) to 106.5(1)°. All the Zn-N and Zn-O bond lengths are in the normal range and comparable to those of the Zn(II)-tetrazole and the Zn(II)-nicotinate compounds.

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of Zn2+ center in compound 1 with the thermal ellipsoids drawn at the 30% probability level. All H atoms of C atoms are omitted for clarity (symmetry codes: (i) −x, −y, z; (ii) −x, y, −0.5 + z). (b) View of 2D cation layer [Zn2(nic)2(OH)]+ along the ac plane. (c) View of the 3D packing diagram. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity except the H atoms of the free water and hydroxide groups. (d) View of the 4-connected “irl” topological net of 1 with the Schläfli symbol of (42·63·8) (cyan: Zn nodes).
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination environment of Zn2+ center in compound 1 with the thermal ellipsoids drawn at the 30% probability level. All H atoms of C atoms are omitted for clarity (symmetry codes: (i) -x, -y, z; (ii) -x, y, -0.5 + z). (b) View of 2D cation layer [Zn2(nic)2(OH)]+ along the ac plane. (c) View of the 3D packing diagram. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity except the H atoms of the free water and hydroxide groups. (d) View of the 4-connected "irl" topological net of 1 with the Schläfli symbol of (42⋅63⋅8) (cyan: Zn nodes).

elements.content: In this structure, the Zn atoms are bridged into a zigzag chain by a μ2-nic– (N,O) ligand along the c-axis direction; then Zn atoms of the two adjacent chains are connected together by hydroxide groups with an interval of one Zn atom and form a 2D cation layer [Zn2(nic)2(OH)]+ (b) along the ac plane. Adjacent layers are linked together through the μ2-metz– ligands and the residual coordination sites of Zn2+ ions and result in a 3D framework (c). Considering Zn2+ ions as 4-connected nodes, the connections representing nic–, metz–, and hydroxide groups, respectively, compound 1 can also be simplified as a 4-connected “irl” topological network with the Schläfli symbol of (42·63·8) (d).
elements.clean_text: In this structure, the Zn atoms are bridged into a zigzag chain by a μ2-nic- (N,O) ligand along the c-axis direction; then Zn atoms of the two adjacent chains are connected together by hydroxide groups with an interval of one Zn atom and form a 2D cation layer [Zn2(nic)2(OH)]+ (b) along the ac plane. Adjacent layers are linked together through the μ2-metz- ligands and the residual coordination sites of Zn2+ ions and result in a 3D framework (c). Considering Zn2+ ions as 4-connected nodes, the connections representing nic-, metz-, and hydroxide groups, respectively, compound 1 can also be simplified as a 4-connected "irl" topological network with the Schläfli symbol of (42⋅63⋅8) (d).

elements.content: Complex 2 crystallizes in an acentric space group Pc, which belongs to the polar point group (Cs), and the asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent Zn­(II) centers, two phtz ligands, and two inc ligands. The Zn­(II) atoms and nic and phtz ligands are all sited in the general position. Zn1 and Zn2 atoms are four-coordinated and adopt a tetrahedral geometry (a). Each of the Zn­(II) atom is surrounded by three N atoms and one O atom, in which the N atoms come from two independent phtz ligands and one nic ligand, and the O atom comes from the other nic ligand. The Zn–N bond distances range from 1.996(9) to 2.036(7) Å. The Zn1–O1and Zn2–O3 bond distances are 1.920(5) and 1.938(3) Å, respectively, which are all in the normal range. The cis-angles at central Zn1 and Zn2 ions fall in the ranges of 98.8(2)–115.2(2)° and 100.7(2)–118.3(2)°, which indicates that the tetrahedral geometry around the Zn atom is slightly distorted.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Zn(phtz)(nic)]2n  (2)

Complex 2 crystallizes in an acentric space group Pc, which belongs to the polar point group (Cs), and the asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent Zn(II) centers, two phtz ligands, and two inc ligands. The Zn(II) atoms and nic and phtz ligands are all sited in the general position. Zn1 and Zn2 atoms are four-coordinated and adopt a tetrahedral geometry (a). Each of the Zn(II) atom is surrounded by three N atoms and one O atom, in which the N atoms come from two independent phtz ligands and one nic ligand, and the O atom comes from the other nic ligand. The Zn-N bond distances range from 1.996(9) to 2.036(7) Å. The Zn1-O1and Zn2-O3 bond distances are 1.920(5) and 1.938(3) Å, respectively, which are all in the normal range. The cis-angles at central Zn1 and Zn2 ions fall in the ranges of 98.8(2)-115.2(2)° and 100.7(2)-118.3(2)°, which indicates that the tetrahedral geometry around the Zn atom is slightly distorted.

elements.content: (a) View of the coordination environment of Zn2+ in compound 2 (30% probability). All of the H atoms are omitted for clarity (symmetry codes: (i) x, −y, 0.5 + z; (ii) 1 + x, y, z). (b) View of the 2D pleat layer along the ac plane. (c) View of the 4-connected “sql” topological net of 2 with the Schläfli symbol of (42·62) (cyan: Zn node). (d) Packing diagram of 2.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) View of the coordination environment of Zn2+ in compound 2 (30% probability). All of the H atoms are omitted for clarity (symmetry codes: (i) x, -y, 0.5 + z; (ii) 1 + x, y, z). (b) View of the 2D pleat layer along the ac plane. (c) View of the 4-connected "sql" topological net of 2 with the Schläfli symbol of (42⋅62) (cyan: Zn node). (d) Packing diagram of 2.

elements.content: In this structure, the Zn1 and Zn2 atoms are bridged into a linear chain by μ2-nic– (N,O) ligands along the a axis direction. The dihedral angles between the adjacent carboxyl groups of nic ligands of the linear chain are 84.30°. Adjacent linear chains are linked into a 2D layer through the bridging phtz– ligands and the residual coordination sites of Zn2+ ions along the ac plane with the dihedral angles about 94° between the adjacent pleats (b). The 2D layers stack up through the intermolecular forces, leading to a 3D supramolecular framework formation (d). Topologically, the 2D network can be viewed as an “sql” topology with the Schläfli symbol of 44·62 when the four coordination Zn­(II) ions are regarded as 4-connected nodes and the organic ligands as linkers (c).
elements.clean_text: In this structure, the Zn1 and Zn2 atoms are bridged into a linear chain by μ2-nic- (N,O) ligands along the a axis direction. The dihedral angles between the adjacent carboxyl groups of nic ligands of the linear chain are 84.30°. Adjacent linear chains are linked into a 2D layer through the bridging phtz- ligands and the residual coordination sites of Zn2+ ions along the ac plane with the dihedral angles about 94° between the adjacent pleats (b). The 2D layers stack up through the intermolecular forces, leading to a 3D supramolecular framework formation (d). Topologically, the 2D network can be viewed as an "sql" topology with the Schläfli symbol of 44⋅62 when the four coordination Zn(II) ions are regarded as 4-connected nodes and the organic ligands as linkers (c).

elements.content: Both the structures of 1 and 2 contain 1D chains. Zigzag chains exist in 1, whereas linear chains are observed in 2. The difference originates from the different connective forms between the intrachains. In compound 1, the adjacent chains are connected together by hydroxide groups through the intervals of Zn atoms and form the zigzag chains, then leading to the 2D layer formation. At the same time, one of the coordination sites on each Zn2+ ion still remains. Therefore, the adjacent layers can be linked to each other through the residual coordination sites of Zn2+ ions and the bridging metz– ligands, resulting in the 3D framework in 1. In structure 2, adjacent chains are linked together through bridging phtz– ligands along two different directions without intervals of Zn atoms, and then form a 2D layer. It is not like compound 1, no residual coordination sites of Zn2+ ions remain in 2. Although the synthesis was performed under the same reaction conditions, the bridging hydroxide group was not observed in compound 2; instead, phtz– ligand was used as bridging ligand to connect the chains together to give 2D structure. The two distinctly different structures are probably a result of electronic and/or steric effects of the tetrazole-based ligand. The large steric hindrance of the phtz– ligand leads to the formation of a 2D layered network.
elements.clean_text: Both the structures of 1 and 2 contain 1D chains. Zigzag chains exist in 1, whereas linear chains are observed in 2. The difference originates from the different connective forms between the intrachains. In compound 1, the adjacent chains are connected together by hydroxide groups through the intervals of Zn atoms and form the zigzag chains, then leading to the 2D layer formation. At the same time, one of the coordination sites on each Zn2+ ion still remains. Therefore, the adjacent layers can be linked to each other through the residual coordination sites of Zn2+ ions and the bridging metz- ligands, resulting in the 3D framework in 1. In structure 2, adjacent chains are linked together through bridging phtz- ligands along two different directions without intervals of Zn atoms, and then form a 2D layer. It is not like compound 1, no residual coordination sites of Zn2+ ions remain in 2. Although the synthesis was performed under the same reaction conditions, the bridging hydroxide group was not observed in compound 2; instead, phtz- ligand was used as bridging ligand to connect the chains together to give 2D structure. The two distinctly different structures are probably a result of electronic and/or steric effects of the tetrazole-based ligand. The large steric hindrance of the phtz- ligand leads to the formation of a 2D layered network.

elements.content: The crystalline phase purities for 1 and 2 were confirmed by the PXRD patterns. As shown in the PXRD patterns (), the major peak positions of the PXRD patterns of the bulk solids of 1 and 2 matched well with the simulated patterns, which confirms the phase purity of the as-prepared products. In order to examine the thermal stabilities of the two compounds, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a N2 atm in the temperature range of 30–600 °C. As shown in , the TGA curves indicate that the two compounds are stable up to a high temperature (300 °C for 1 and 320 °C for 2). Beyond this temperature, the skeletons of the structures collapse, perhaps because of the decomposition of the organic ligands. The first weight loss is 2.23% (calcd 1.86%) between 30 and 120 °C for 1, corresponding to the loss of the free water molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction and Thermal Stability

The crystalline phase purities for 1 and 2 were confirmed by the PXRD patterns. As shown in the PXRD patterns (), the major peak positions of the PXRD patterns of the bulk solids of 1 and 2 matched well with the simulated patterns, which confirms the phase purity of the as-prepared products. In order to examine the thermal stabilities of the two compounds, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a N2 atm in the temperature range of 30-600 °C. As shown in , the TGA curves indicate that the two compounds are stable up to a high temperature (300 °C for 1 and 320 °C for 2). Beyond this temperature, the skeletons of the structures collapse, perhaps because of the decomposition of the organic ligands. The first weight loss is 2.23% (calcd 1.86%) between 30 and 120 °C for 1, corresponding to the loss of the free water molecules.

elements.content: As is known, only the noncentrosymmetric structure might have a second-order nonlinear optical effect. Both of the two crystallized in an acentric space group (Ccc2 for 1 and Pc for 2). Therefore, the second-harmonic generation (SHG) measurements were investigated. Approximate estimations were carried out on a pulsed Q-switched Nd:YAG laser at a wavelength of 1064 nm. The results obtained from a powdered sample (80–150 mm diameter) in the form of a pellet (Kurtz powder test) were compared with those obtained for urea. The preliminary experimental results revealed that compounds 1 and 2 display modest powder SHG efficiencies of 0.7 and 0.4 times that of urea (7 and 4 times that of KDP), respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Nonlinear Optical Properties

As is known, only the noncentrosymmetric structure might have a second-order nonlinear optical effect. Both of the two crystallized in an acentric space group (Ccc2 for 1 and Pc for 2). Therefore, the second-harmonic generation (SHG) measurements were investigated. Approximate estimations were carried out on a pulsed Q-switched Nd:YAG laser at a wavelength of 1064 nm. The results obtained from a powdered sample (80-150 mm diameter) in the form of a pellet (Kurtz powder test) were compared with those obtained for urea. The preliminary experimental results revealed that compounds 1 and 2 display modest powder SHG efficiencies of 0.7 and 0.4 times that of urea (7 and 4 times that of KDP), respectively.

elements.content: As mentioned above, both of the two compounds crystallize in the acentric space groups, C 2v for 1, Cs for 2, and both belong to the 10 polar point groups (C 1, C s , C 2, C 2v , C 4, C 4v , C 3, C 3v , C 6, C 6v ) required for the ferroelectric property. Our primarily experimental results reveal that there are electric hysteresis loops in compound 1 with remnant polarization (P r) of 1.22–2.9 μC cm–2, a coercive field (E c) of 1.29–2.57 kV cm–1, and a saturation spontaneous polarization (P s) of 2.61–6.26 μC cm–2 (). Similarly, as illustrated in , the P r, E c, and P s of compound 2 are 2.55–5.27 μC cm–2, 0.45–1.42 V cm–1, and 0.85–2.50 μC cm–2, respectively. The P s values of the two compounds are comparable with those of the classical organic–inorganic ferroelectrics triglycine sulfate (TGS: P s = 3.0 μC cm–2) and NaKC4H4O6·4H2O (Rosal salt: P s = 0.25 μC cm–2). In order to confirm the ferroelectricity mentioned above for 1 and 2, the leakage currents are further investigated. As shown in , the leakage currents show no alterations and keep extremely low valves (less than 10–6 A for 1 and 10–5 A for 2) under the employed conditions, so the observed hysteresis loop is clearly due to ferroelectricity.
elements.clean_text:
Ferroelectric Properties

As mentioned above, both of the two compounds crystallize in the acentric space groups, C 2v  for 1, Cs for 2, and both belong to the 10 polar point groups (C 1, C  s , C 2, C 2v , C 4, C 4v , C 3, C 3v , C 6, C 6v ) required for the ferroelectric property. Our primarily experimental results reveal that there are electric hysteresis loops in compound 1 with remnant polarization (P r) of 1.22-2.9 μC cm-2, a coercive field (E c) of 1.29-2.57 kV cm-1, and a saturation spontaneous polarization (P s) of 2.61-6.26 μC cm-2 (). Similarly, as illustrated in , the P r, E c, and P s of compound 2 are 2.55-5.27 μC cm-2, 0.45-1.42 V cm-1, and 0.85-2.50 μC cm-2, respectively. The P s values of the two compounds are comparable with those of the classical organic-inorganic ferroelectrics triglycine sulfate (TGS: P s = 3.0 μC cm-2) and NaKC4H4O6⋅4H2O (Rosal salt: P s = 0.25 μC cm-2). In order to confirm the ferroelectricity mentioned above for 1 and 2, the leakage currents are further investigated. As shown in , the leakage currents show no alterations and keep extremely low valves (less than 10-6 A for 1 and 10-5 A for 2) under the employed conditions, so the observed hysteresis loop is clearly due to ferroelectricity.

elements.content: Electric hysteresis loops of powder pellet samples of 1 and 2 recorded at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 3  Electric hysteresis loops of powder pellet samples of 1 and 2 recorded at room temperature.

elements.content: Owing to the excellent luminescence properties of zinc complexes, the solid-state fluorescent properties of the two compounds were investigated at room temperature. As illustrated in , upon excitation of these solid samples at 323 nm for 1 and 313 nm for 2, the intense broad emission bands at 446 nm for 1 and at 393, 454, and 488 nm for 2 are observed. The free Hnic exhibits fluorescent emission bands at 379 and 512 nm (λex = 330 nm) (), while the free Hatz ligand presents a weak photoluminescence emission at 325 nm, according to the reported literature. Taking the emission bands of these free organic ligands into consideration, the emissions of 1 may also be ascribed to the cooperative effects of intraligand emission and ligand-to-metal charge transition (LMCT). The fluorescence differences between the two compounds may be ascribed to the different substituents at the 5-position of the tetrazole ligands of zinc ions and/or their local coordination environments. Combining with their high thermal stabilities, compounds 1 and 2 can be considered as potential candidates for blue-light-emitting materials.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent Properties

Owing to the excellent luminescence properties of zinc complexes, the solid-state fluorescent properties of the two compounds were investigated at room temperature. As illustrated in , upon excitation of these solid samples at 323 nm for 1 and 313 nm for 2, the intense broad emission bands at 446 nm for 1 and at 393, 454, and 488 nm for 2 are observed. The free Hnic exhibits fluorescent emission bands at 379 and 512 nm (λex = 330 nm) (), while the free Hatz ligand presents a weak photoluminescence emission at 325 nm, according to the reported literature. Taking the emission bands of these free organic ligands into consideration, the emissions of 1 may also be ascribed to the cooperative effects of intraligand emission and ligand-to-metal charge transition (LMCT). The fluorescence differences between the two compounds may be ascribed to the different substituents at the 5-position of the tetrazole ligands of zinc ions and/or their local coordination environments. Combining with their high thermal stabilities, compounds 1 and 2 can be considered as potential candidates for blue-light-emitting materials.

elements.content: Solid-state fluorescence spectra of compounds 1 and 3 at RT (λex: 323 nm for 1 and 313 nm for 2).
elements.clean_text: 4  Solid-state fluorescence spectra of compounds 1 and 3 at RT (λex: 323 nm for 1 and 313 nm for 2).

elements.content: In summary, two new multifunctional zinc coordination polymers have been successfully prepared and structurally characterized. The synergetic effect of both the symmetric and the asymmetric ligands endows the materials with unique structures and properties. This work indicates that combining the asymmetric bridging ligand with the tetrazole-based ligand can be an efficient method to generate multifunctional materials with NLO-active, ferroelectric behaviors, and fluorescent properties. The strategy can be a general method for searching for interesting multifunctional organic–inorganic hybrid materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, two new multifunctional zinc coordination polymers have been successfully prepared and structurally characterized. The synergetic effect of both the symmetric and the asymmetric ligands endows the materials with unique structures and properties. This work indicates that combining the asymmetric bridging ligand with the tetrazole-based ligand can be an efficient method to generate multifunctional materials with NLO-active, ferroelectric behaviors, and fluorescent properties. The strategy can be a general method for searching for interesting multifunctional organic-inorganic hybrid materials.

elements.content: Crystallographic data, IR spectrum, PXRD patterns, solid-state excitation and emission spectra for Hnic, thermal stability, and CCDC reference numbers 1055365 for 1 and 105536 for 2. The Supporting Information is available free of charge on the ACS Publications website at DOI: 10.1021/acs.cgd.5b00637.
elements.clean_text: Crystallographic data, IR spectrum, PXRD patterns, solid-state excitation and emission spectra for Hnic, thermal stability, and CCDC reference numbers 1055365 for 1 and 105536 for 2. The Supporting Information is available free of charge on the ACS Publications website at DOI: 10.1021/acs.cgd.5b00637.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of ZnSO4·7H2O (0.575 g, 2 mmol), Hmtz (0.168 g, 2 mmol), Hnic (0.122g, 1.0 mmol), NaOH (0.040g, 1.0 mmol), ethanol (2 mL), and water (8 mL) was stirred for 30 min in air, then sealed in a 23 mL Teflon autoclave, and heated at 130 °C for 3 days. After the sample was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C/h, colorless block crystals were obtained in ca. 38% yield based on Zn. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3450 (m), 2919 (w), 2850 (w), 2343 (w), 1599 (m), 1556 (m), 1488 (s), 1384 (vs), 1249 (m), 1182 (m), 1094 (m), 699 (s), 491 (m). () Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C28H26N12O11Zn4: (M r = 968.09) C, 34.93; H, 2.72; N, 17.47; found: C, 34.08; H, 2.48; N, 17.62.

Synthesis of [Zn­(phtz)­(nic)]<sub>2<italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

Similarly, complex 2 was prepared in the same manner as that for 1 but with Hphtz (0.292 g, 2 mmol) to replace Hmtz. Colorless block crystals were obtained in ca. 32% yield based on Zn. IR (cm–1): 3060 (m), 1610 (m), 1530 (m), 1460 (s), 1390 (s), 1320 (m), 1290 (w), 1200 (w), 1200 (m), 1180 (s), 1020 (s), 931 (m), 854 (w), 783 (s), 731 (s), 687 (s), 600 (m). () Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C26H18N10O4Zn2: (M r = 665.24) C, 46.94; H, 2.73; N, 21.05; found: C, 46.73; H, 2.52; N, 21.32.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

Synthesis of [Zn2(mtz)(nic)2(OH)] n ⋅0.5nH2O (1)

A mixture of ZnSO4⋅7H2O (0.575 g, 2 mmol), Hmtz (0.168 g, 2 mmol), Hnic (0.122g, 1.0 mmol), NaOH (0.040g, 1.0 mmol), ethanol (2 mL), and water (8 mL) was stirred for 30 min in air, then sealed in a 23 mL Teflon autoclave, and heated at 130 °C for 3 days. After the sample was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C/h, colorless block crystals were obtained in ca. 38% yield based on Zn. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3450 (m), 2919 (w), 2850 (w), 2343 (w), 1599 (m), 1556 (m), 1488 (s), 1384 (vs), 1249 (m), 1182 (m), 1094 (m), 699 (s), 491 (m). () Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C28H26N12O11Zn4: (M r = 968.09) C, 34.93; H, 2.72; N, 17.47; found: C, 34.08; H, 2.48; N, 17.62.

Synthesis of [Zn(phtz)(nic)]2n  (2)

Similarly, complex 2 was prepared in the same manner as that for 1 but with Hphtz (0.292 g, 2 mmol) to replace Hmtz. Colorless block crystals were obtained in ca. 32% yield based on Zn. IR (cm-1): 3060 (m), 1610 (m), 1530 (m), 1460 (s), 1390 (s), 1320 (m), 1290 (w), 1200 (w), 1200 (m), 1180 (s), 1020 (s), 931 (m), 854 (w), 783 (s), 731 (s), 687 (s), 600 (m). () Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C26H18N10O4Zn2: (M r = 665.24) C, 46.94; H, 2.73; N, 21.05; found: C, 46.73; H, 2.52; N, 21.32.

cln_elements.content:
The crystalline phase purities for 1 and 2 were confirmed by the PXRD patterns. As shown in the PXRD patterns (), the major peak positions of the PXRD patterns of the bulk solids of 1 and 2 matched well with the simulated patterns, which confirms the phase purity of the as-prepared products. In order to examine the thermal stabilities of the two compounds, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a N2 atm in the temperature range of 30–600 °C. As shown in , the TGA curves indicate that the two compounds are stable up to a high temperature (300 °C for 1 and 320 °C for 2). Beyond this temperature, the skeletons of the structures collapse, perhaps because of the decomposition of the organic ligands. The first weight loss is 2.23% (calcd 1.86%) between 30 and 120 °C for 1, corresponding to the loss of the free water molecules.

Ferroelectric Properties

As mentioned above, both of the two compounds crystallize in the acentric space groups, C 2v for 1, Cs for 2, and both belong to the 10 polar point groups (C 1, C s , C 2, C 2v , C 4, C 4v , C 3, C 3v , C 6, C 6v ) required for the ferroelectric property. Our primarily experimental results reveal that there are electric hysteresis loops in compound 1 with remnant polarization (P r) of 1.22–2.9 μC cm–2, a coercive field (E c) of 1.29–2.57 kV cm–1, and a saturation spontaneous polarization (P s) of 2.61–6.26 μC cm–2 (). Similarly, as illustrated in , the P r, E c, and P s of compound 2 are 2.55–5.27 μC cm–2, 0.45–1.42 V cm–1, and 0.85–2.50 μC cm–2, respectively. The P s values of the two compounds are comparable with those of the classical organic–inorganic ferroelectrics triglycine sulfate (TGS: P s = 3.0 μC cm–2) and NaKC4H4O6·4H2O (Rosal salt: P s = 0.25 μC cm–2). In order to confirm the ferroelectricity mentioned above for 1 and 2, the leakage currents are further investigated. As shown in , the leakage currents show no alterations and keep extremely low valves (less than 10–6 A for 1 and 10–5 A for 2) under the employed conditions, so the observed hysteresis loop is clearly due to ferroelectricity.

Fluorescent Properties

Owing to the excellent luminescence properties of zinc complexes, the solid-state fluorescent properties of the two compounds were investigated at room temperature. As illustrated in , upon excitation of these solid samples at 323 nm for 1 and 313 nm for 2, the intense broad emission bands at 446 nm for 1 and at 393, 454, and 488 nm for 2 are observed. The free Hnic exhibits fluorescent emission bands at 379 and 512 nm (λex = 330 nm) (), while the free Hatz ligand presents a weak photoluminescence emission at 325 nm, according to the reported literature. Taking the emission bands of these free organic ligands into consideration, the emissions of 1 may also be ascribed to the cooperative effects of intraligand emission and ligand-to-metal charge transition (LMCT). The fluorescence differences between the two compounds may be ascribed to the different substituents at the 5-position of the tetrazole ligands of zinc ions and/or their local coordination environments. Combining with their high thermal stabilities, compounds 1 and 2 can be considered as potential candidates for blue-light-emitting materials.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction and Thermal Stability

The crystalline phase purities for 1 and 2 were confirmed by the PXRD patterns. As shown in the PXRD patterns (), the major peak positions of the PXRD patterns of the bulk solids of 1 and 2 matched well with the simulated patterns, which confirms the phase purity of the as-prepared products. In order to examine the thermal stabilities of the two compounds, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a N2 atm in the temperature range of 30-600 °C. As shown in , the TGA curves indicate that the two compounds are stable up to a high temperature (300 °C for 1 and 320 °C for 2). Beyond this temperature, the skeletons of the structures collapse, perhaps because of the decomposition of the organic ligands. The first weight loss is 2.23% (calcd 1.86%) between 30 and 120 °C for 1, corresponding to the loss of the free water molecules.

Ferroelectric Properties

As mentioned above, both of the two compounds crystallize in the acentric space groups, C 2v  for 1, Cs for 2, and both belong to the 10 polar point groups (C 1, C  s , C 2, C 2v , C 4, C 4v , C 3, C 3v , C 6, C 6v ) required for the ferroelectric property. Our primarily experimental results reveal that there are electric hysteresis loops in compound 1 with remnant polarization (P r) of 1.22-2.9 μC cm-2, a coercive field (E c) of 1.29-2.57 kV cm-1, and a saturation spontaneous polarization (P s) of 2.61-6.26 μC cm-2 (). Similarly, as illustrated in , the P r, E c, and P s of compound 2 are 2.55-5.27 μC cm-2, 0.45-1.42 V cm-1, and 0.85-2.50 μC cm-2, respectively. The P s values of the two compounds are comparable with those of the classical organic-inorganic ferroelectrics triglycine sulfate (TGS: P s = 3.0 μC cm-2) and NaKC4H4O6⋅4H2O (Rosal salt: P s = 0.25 μC cm-2). In order to confirm the ferroelectricity mentioned above for 1 and 2, the leakage currents are further investigated. As shown in , the leakage currents show no alterations and keep extremely low valves (less than 10-6 A for 1 and 10-5 A for 2) under the employed conditions, so the observed hysteresis loop is clearly due to ferroelectricity.

Fluorescent Properties

Owing to the excellent luminescence properties of zinc complexes, the solid-state fluorescent properties of the two compounds were investigated at room temperature. As illustrated in , upon excitation of these solid samples at 323 nm for 1 and 313 nm for 2, the intense broad emission bands at 446 nm for 1 and at 393, 454, and 488 nm for 2 are observed. The free Hnic exhibits fluorescent emission bands at 379 and 512 nm (λex = 330 nm) (), while the free Hatz ligand presents a weak photoluminescence emission at 325 nm, according to the reported literature. Taking the emission bands of these free organic ligands into consideration, the emissions of 1 may also be ascribed to the cooperative effects of intraligand emission and ligand-to-metal charge transition (LMCT). The fluorescence differences between the two compounds may be ascribed to the different substituents at the 5-position of the tetrazole ligands of zinc ions and/or their local coordination environments. Combining with their high thermal stabilities, compounds 1 and 2 can be considered as potential candidates for blue-light-emitting materials.

| absolute structure parameter | 0.038(18)                    | 0.010(15)                               |
| max peak, hole/(e·Å<sup>3</sup>) | 0.452, −0.447              | 0.411, −0.413                           |

Table 1 Footnotes:
a. R1 = ∑||Fo| – |Fc||/∑|Fo|.
b. wR2 = [∑w(Fo^2 – Fc^2)^2/∑w(Fo^2)^2]^1/2.
<END>

All H atoms of C atoms are omitted for clarity (symmetry codes: (i) −x, −y, z; (ii) −x, y, −0.5 + z). (b) View of 2D cation layer [Zn2(nic)2(OH)]+ along the ac plane. (c) View of the 3D packing diagram. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity except the H atoms of the free water and hydroxide groups. (d) View of the 4-connected “irl” topological net of 1 with the Schläfli symbol of (42·63·8) (cyan: Zn nodes).
